articles.headline: California High Court Upholds Gay Marriage Ban
articles.snippet: The ruling ratified a decision made by voters last year, but allowed existing gay marriages to stand.
articles.abstract: The ruling ratified a decision made by voters last year, but allowed existing gay marriages to stand.
articles.lead_paragraph: The California Supreme Court upheld a ban on same-sex marriage Tuesday, ratifying a decision made by voters last year. The ruling comes at a time when several state governments have moved in the opposite direction.

articles.headline: Russians Spend Big for a Piece of Facebook
articles.snippet: Digital Sky Technologies invested $200 million in the social networking company in return for a 1.96 percent stake.
articles.abstract: Digital Sky Technologies invested $200 million in the social networking company in return for a 1.96 percent stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Russian investment firm, Digital Sky Technologies, has invested $200 million in the social networking company Facebook in return for a 1.96 percent stake, the two companies said Tuesday.

articles.headline: U.S. Expected to Own 70% of Restructured G.M.
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers would hold up to 20 percent of General Motors through its retiree health care fund, and shareholders would be virtually wiped out.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers would hold up to 20 percent of General Motors through its retiree health care fund, and shareholders would be virtually wiped out.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  In better times, many employees of General Motors called their company “Generous Motors” because of its rich benefits.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Big Oil Warms to Ethanol and Biofuel Companies
articles.snippet: With demand for gasoline, and the ethanol that goes into it, expected to rise, oil companies are trying to benefit.
articles.abstract: With demand for gasoline, and the ethanol that goes into it, expected to rise, oil companies are trying to benefit.
articles.lead_paragraph: JENNINGS, La.  For decades, the big oil companies and the farm lobby have been fighting about ethanol, with the farmers pushing to produce more of it and the refiners arguing it was a boondoggle that would do little to solve the country’s energy problems.

articles.headline: Recession Imperils Loan Forgiveness Programs
articles.snippet: Cutbacks in loan forgiveness programs could result in fewer students going into fields like teaching and nursing.
articles.abstract: Cutbacks in loan forgiveness programs could result in fewer students going into fields like teaching and nursing.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a Kentucky agency cut back its program to forgive student loans for schoolteachers, Travis B. Gay knew he and his wife, Stephanie  both special-education teachers  were in trouble.

articles.headline: Nominee’s Rulings Are Exhaustive but Often Narrow
articles.snippet: Judge Sonia Sotomayor’s opinions are marked by diligence, depth and unflashy competence, but reveal no larger vision.
articles.abstract: Judge Sonia Sotomayor’s opinions are marked by diligence, depth and unflashy competence, but reveal no larger vision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Judge Sonia Sotomayor’s judicial opinions are marked by diligence, depth and unflashy competence. If they are not always a pleasure to read, they are usually models of modern judicial craftsmanship, which prizes careful attention to the facts in the record and a methodical application of layers of legal principles.

articles.headline: Financial Careers Come at a Cost to Families
articles.snippet: Among elite white-collar fields, finance appears to be hardest for achieving a balance between work and family.
articles.abstract: Among elite white-collar fields, finance appears to be hardest for achieving a balance between work and family.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big influx of highly educated workers into finance in the last two decades has been the subject of some national hand-wringing lately. President Obama, college presidents and economists have all worried aloud that Wall Street has hoarded human resources that might otherwise have gone to science, education, medicine or other fields.

articles.headline: On Paper, Prudential Gets a Lift
articles.snippet: Prudential Financial jumped nearly 30 percent this month on news that it was profitable again. Largely overlooked was that the profit came solely from accounting.
articles.abstract: Prudential Financial jumped nearly 30 percent this month on news that it was profitable again. Largely overlooked was that the profit came solely from accounting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors eagerly looking for the “green shoots” of a recovery lapped up the news when Prudential Financial announced this month that it was profitable again, after six months of big losses.

articles.headline: Sotomayor, a Trailblazer and a Dreamer
articles.snippet: Judge Sotomayor’s up-by-the-bootstraps tale, which in many ways mirrors President Obama’s, is one reason for her selection.
articles.abstract: Judge Sotomayor’s up-by-the-bootstraps tale, which in many ways mirrors President Obama’s, is one reason for her selection.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  She was “a child with dreams,” as she once said, the little girl who learned at 8 that she had diabetes, who lost her father when she was 9, who devoured Nancy Drew books and spent Saturday nights playing bingo, marking the cards with chickpeas, in the squat red brick housing projects of the East Bronx.

articles.headline: Inflation Fears Push Up Bond Yields
articles.snippet: Investors have been far more willing to buy short-term Treasury bonds, widening the yield gap between two-year and 10-year notes.
articles.abstract: Investors have been far more willing to buy short-term Treasury bonds, widening the yield gap between two-year and 10-year notes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is spending more than $1 trillion to keep interest rates low and help credit flow, but investors are getting worried that those efforts are starting to falter.
